I think the wiki is a better place for proposals. Here's some advantages of the wiki:

1. All of our existing proposals and technical documentation is already there. Someone searching for information only has to search one place.
2. It easily supports embedding diagrams and other pictures into the proposal, which is important for complicated concepts.
3. You get to to review and comment inline the formatted text, not the plain text version
4. Finished RFCs are more easily discoverable - the wiki is indexed on google, and the geode space is searchable on the wiki without finding code as well.
5. Content from RFCs can be easily linked to or incorporated into our Architectural overview
6. Proposals that span multiple geode repositories have a reasonable place to stay.
7. The wiki is purpose built for technical documention. github is designed for storing code. Lots of little things (like how search results show up, how you add images to docs, how you link docs) work better on the wiki because that's what it is designed for.

> Would this process replace sending [PROPOSAL] emails to the dev list?

I  don't think it should. Most people aren't watching all of the github PRs, so they would never see RFCs in time. RFCs need more visibility, so they should be immediately sent to the mailing list and clearly labeled.

so, user would need to constantly issue "list index" until they see all the indexes are in "finished" state, and then start doing data provisioning? what's would cause the index to be in "maintenance mode"? Should we make that command wait till it finished before it returns instead? Also Jason mentioned that even if an index could be in "finished" state, a few puts would make it back to "maintenance" mode again, so, you really can't rely on what's shown currently on the gfsh output.

"if it didn't happen on the dev list, it didn't happen"

I'm not convinced that we need to impose any additional process here.  We already use the formalisms of time-boxed [DISCUSS] and [VOTE] threads via the dev list.  We [already](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/GEODE/Project+Proposals+and+Specifications) use the wiki to capture design documentation and evolve it from proposal to prototype to completed feature.  We already have GitHub and the PR process to review implementation details as the feature is realized.  

Apache values people over process.  It sounds like the problem trying to be solved here is "consensus on design decisions take a very long time".  Agreeing to use [Rough consensus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rough_consensus) might be all that's needed to keep things moving forward.

That said, there are some great ideas in this proposal.  I would love to see them captured as "guidelines" at the top of https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/GEODE/Project+Proposals+and+Specifications

> For some users, it is important to be able to check whether data and indexes are consistent.

With `asynchronous` maintenance we can't guarantee this fact **unless** the data within the region is unchanged and no operations are being executed **at all** on that particular region. I'm just thinking that this feature might just confuse users instead of helping them.

I like this idea of using PRs instead of wiki/emails for RFCs because of the reasons already stated, as well as
- It's easy to see the voting status in the "Reviewers" side pane, as well as a voting summary at the bottom of the PR. With emails I have to scroll through every email and tally the votes in my head each time.
- It's easy to see when the RFC is still in the "voting" state by whether or not it is open/merged/closed. It's hard to know on the dev list when a consensus has been reached.
- With PRs, changes can only be accepted by Geode committers by merging the PR. Permissions on the wiki are more lax. For example, I have permission to edit the wiki but not permission to commit directly to Geode.

EDIT: Just to clarify, I'd be fine with the wiki approach as well -- PR is just my preference. The main thing is that I'm happy to see the template for proposals as well as the "lazy majority" consensus model and timeline.
Use case is, create indexes on empty database. Then put data. And after all data are inserted, check whether data and indexes are consistent, so you can start with queries.

> Use case is, create indexes on empty database. Then put data. And after all data are inserted, check whether data and indexes are consistent, so you can start with queries.

Understood but, even in this case, the command is not reliable as it only gives the user a "snapshot" of the index update status at a given point in time. As an example, after the user has finished populating a **huge amount** of data into the cluster, how long should they wait to execute the command?, how many times should they execute the command until they're strongly convinced the index maintenance is over?. If, as a user, I need to ask myself these questions before using a feature, I'd strongly doubt to use it in the first place.
Please don't get me wrong, I'm not just criticising for the sake of it, it's just that I'm not strongly convinced of the usefulness of this feature.
Just my two cents, anyway.

I do agree with Owen that this process should be a way of building consensus and getting feedback on a larger change - not about voting an formally ratifying a document. I don't think we should be overly concerned with voting on these things at all - at the end of the day, sending an RFC is up to the committer to decide and following it afterwards is up to the committer as well.

On the wiki vs. PR thing - how about we just give people creating an RFC a choice of either for a little while, and then discuss which is working better. Once we do a few I think we will have more informed opinions.

I do very much like Jake's suggestion of seeing this RFC through as a PR. I also like Dan's idea of giving people a choice and see which one we like better. I do think though, that in that case we should make sure that the RFC also gets added to the wiki once approved. I am happy to do that work for this PR.

I understand the need to separate concerns into different interfaces, but if they are always used together, It's probably a good idea to lump them into one concept for better understanding and readability. Everywhere in the code I see `T extends CacheElement & RespondsWith<R>`, which indicates that we can bake `RespondWith<R>` into `CacheElement`.  If you declare `CacheElement` as 
```public abstract class CacheElement<R extends CacheElement> implements Identifiable<String>, Serializable```

I would prefer you separate these two tasks."  The result of separating out what "creates a link between the static config and the runtime config" is `RespondsWith`.

When I proposed this RFC, I set expectations to wrap this up by today. In summary we seem to have largely found consensus on:
* What to cover in an RFC?
* When to write and RFC?
* How to write an RFC?
* Associating a date with an RFC?
* When to write and RFC?

We do not have consensus on:
1. Should proposals live in the wiki or the code base?
2. Should discussion of a proposal happen
    1. In a PR
    2. In a [discuss] thread referencing a proposal in the wiki
    3. In the wiki itself

Given how many people actively work on this project Id love to see a little wider participation on the location question we disagree on. 

 ## Summary of Location discussion
It seems that in the discussion so far we have been conflating where the discussion happens and where the proposals go afterwards. Jake, Dan and others have done a great job at listing lots of pros and cons of wiki vs. PR, let me try to split the arguments for the two different decisions we need to make:

## Where do we keep proposals?
### Proposals live in the wiki
1. All of our existing proposals and technical documentation is already there. Someone searching for information only has to search one place.
2. It easily supports embedding diagrams and other pictures into the proposal, which is important for complicated concepts.
3. Finished RFCs are more easily discoverable - the wiki is indexed on google, and the geode space is searchable on the wiki without finding code as well.
4. Content from RFCs can be easily linked to or incorporated into our Architectural overview
5. Proposals that span multiple geode repositories have a reasonable place to stay.
6. The wiki is purpose built for technical documentation. github is designed for storing code. Lots of little things (like how search results show up, how you add images to docs, how you link docs) work better on the wiki because that's what it is designed for.

### Proposals live in the code base
1. Keeps RFC and errata changes documented with code changes in time
2. Keeps RFC with sources it effects
3. With PRs, changes can only be accepted by Geode committers by merging the PR.

## Where do we discuss proposals?
### Discussion happens in the wiki
1. You get to to review and comment inline the formatted text, not the plain text version
2. Proposals that span multiple geode repositories have a reasonable place to stay.
3. Has threading of comments

### Discussion happens in a PR
1. Has bidirectional email integration
2. Has single place to have discussion
Discussion happens in the dev list (assuming doc lives in the wiki):
3. Has inline comments
4. It's easy to see the voting status in the "Reviewers" side pane, as well as a voting summary at the bottom of the PR.
5. It's easy to see when the RFC is still in the "voting" state by whether or not it is open/merged/closed

### Discussion happens only on the dev list
 1. Highly visible to all contributors.
 2. Very low barrier of entry.

(I left Discussion on dev list + gets submitted via PR out, since that combination makes no sense to me)

Lets give this discussion a little bit more time till EoD Monday 6/24 and then wrap this up. If we cannot get a clear majority, I propose that we keep proposals in the wiki, since thats the smallest change.

Given the discussion so far, my own vote is
1. Proposals live in the wiki
2. Proposals get discussed in the wiki

shutdown(): - Initiates an orderly shutdown in which previously submitted tasks are executed, but no new tasks will be accepted. Invocation has no additional effect if already shut down.

shutdownNow(): - Attempts to stop all actively executing tasks, halts the processing of waiting tasks, and returns a list of the tasks that were awaiting execution.

- or after waiting for initial 120 secs, shutdown all pending tasks

@Petahhh @jmelchio @jackw26

This code change is after the issue has already happened. We can do this, but it doesn't address the issue.

The issue is that when a member is stopped, the shutdown hook attempts to stop the InternalResourceManager's scheduledExecutor. If that executor has any pending tasks (including ones in the future), the shutdown hook blocks waiting for them to fire.

If I run this test:

1. Start 3 servers defining a partitioned region with recovery-delay > 0
2. Load some data into the partitioned region
3. Kill one server using kill -9
4. The remaining servers schedule the recovery task
5. Stop the remaining servers normally (the JVMs do not stop)

The shutdown hook thread is waiting here for the InternalResourceManager's scheduledExecutor to terminate:
```
"Distributed system shutdown hook" #12 prio=5 os_prio=31 tid=0x00007ff0f8c33000 nid=0x12307 waiting on condition [0x000070000bc11000]
   java.lang.Thread.State: TIMED_WAITING (parking)
	at sun.misc.Unsafe.park(Native Method)
	- parking to wait for  <0x0000000766c00038> (a java.util.concurrent.locks.AbstractQueuedSynchronizer$ConditionObject)
	at java.util.concurrent.locks.LockSupport.parkNanos(LockSupport.java:215)
	at java.util.concurrent.locks.AbstractQueuedSynchronizer$ConditionObject.awaitNanos(AbstractQueuedSynchronizer.java:2078)
	at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.awaitTermination(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1465)
	at org.apache.geode.internal.cache.control.InternalResourceManager.stopExecutor(InternalResourceManager.java:343)
	at org.apache.geode.internal.cache.control.InternalResourceManager.close(InternalResourceManager.java:156)
	at org.apache.geode.internal.cache.GemFireCacheImpl.close(GemFireCacheImpl.java:2079)
	- locked <0x0000000766665b58> (a java.lang.Class for org.apache.geode.internal.cache.GemFireCacheImpl)
	at org.apache.geode.distributed.internal.InternalDistributedSystem.disconnect(InternalDistributedSystem.java:1516)
	- locked <0x0000000766665b58> (a java.lang.Class for org.apache.geode.internal.cache.GemFireCacheImpl)
	at org.apache.geode.distributed.internal.InternalDistributedSystem.lambda$static$6(InternalDistributedSystem.java:2181)
	at org.apache.geode.distributed.internal.InternalDistributedSystem$$Lambda$8/111900554.run(Unknown Source)
	at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:745)
```
InternalResourceManager.stopExecutor waits up to 120 seconds to stop:
```
void stopExecutor(ExecutorService executor) {
  if (executor == null) {
    return;
  }
  executor.shutdown();
  final int secToWait = Integer
      .getInteger(DistributionConfig.GEMFIRE_PREFIX + "prrecovery-close-timeout", 120).intValue();
  try {
    executor.awaitTermination(secToWait, TimeUnit.SECONDS);
  } catch (InterruptedException x) {
    Thread.currentThread().interrupt();
    logger.debug("Failed in interrupting the Resource Manager Thread due to interrupt");
  }
  if (!executor.isTerminated()) {
    logger.warn("Failed to stop resource manager threads in {} seconds",
        secToWait);
  }
}
```
I added some logging that shows the sequence of events.

The logging shows the redundancy recovery task being scheduled when the first server is killed (steps 3 and 4 above):
```
[warn 2019/06/24 14:09:21.014 PDT <DM-MemberEventInvoker> tid=0x15] PRHARedundancyProvider.scheduleRedundancyRecovery about to schedule task with delay=30000
```
Then, the shutdown hook is invoked when the server is stopped which causes the InternalResourceManager to wait. The 1 task below is the redundancy recovery task:

It looks like there are a few things that can be done to address this:

1. Don't wait to shutdown the executor. Just shut it down immediately. I'm not sure the consequences of this. In the above case, I'm not sure there are any, but there are other cases.
2. Don't schedule the redundancy recovery task for sometime in the future. Wait for the future to arrive and then schedule it. Darrel suggested this in one of his comments.
